description: From Middle English lawe, laȝe, from Old English lagu (“law”), borrowed from Old Norse lǫg (“law”, literally “things laid down or firmly established”), originally the plural of lag (“layer, stratum, a laying in order, measure, stroke”), from Proto-Germanic *lagą (“that which is laid down”), from Proto-Indo-European *legʰ- (“to lie”). Cognate with Scots law (“law”), Icelandic lög (“things laid down, law”), Faroese lóg (“law”), Norwegian lov (“law”), Swedish lag (“law”), Danish lov (“law”). Replaced Old English ǣ and ġesetnes. More at lay.
Not related to legal, nor to French loi, Spanish ley, all of which ultimately derive from Latin lēx, from Proto-Indo-European *leǵ- (“to gather”).

definitionGroups.group: (usually with "the") The body of binding rules and regulations, customs, and standards established in a community by its legislative and judicial authorities.

entries.meaning: The body of such rules that pertain to a particular topic.
examples: property law
commercial hunting and fishing law

entries.meaning: Common law, as contrasted with equity.
A binding regulation or custom established in a community in this way.
examples: There is a law against importing wallabies.
A new law forbids driving on that road.
The court ruled that the executive order was not law and nullified it.

entries.meaning: Any rule that must or should be obeyed, concerning behaviours and their consequences. (Compare mores.)
examples: "Do unto others as you wish them to do unto you" is a good law to follow.
the law of self-preservation

entries.meaning: A rule or principle regarding the construction of language or art.
examples: the laws of playwriting and poetry

entries.meaning: A statement (in physics, etc) of an (observed, established) order or sequence or relationship of phenomena which is invariable under certain conditions. (Compare theory.)
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:law of nature

entries.meaning: (mathematics, logic) A statement (of relation) that is true under specified conditions; a mathematical or logical rule.
examples: Mathematical laws can be proved purely through mathematics, without scientific experimentation.

entries.meaning: Any statement of the relation of acts and conditions to their consequences.
examples: the law of scarcity
the law of supply and demand

entries.meaning: (linguistics) A sound law; a regular change in the pronunciation of a language.
examples: Grimm's law
Dahl's law

entries.meaning: (cricket) One of the official rules of cricket as codified by the its (former) governing body, the MCC.
The control and order brought about by the observance of such rules.
examples: They worked to maintain law and order.
It was a territory without law, marked by violence.

entries.meaning: (informal) A person or group that act(s) with authority to uphold such rules and order (for example, one or more police officers).
examples: Here comes the law — run!
then the law arrived on the scene

entries.meaning: The profession that deals with such rules (as lawyers, judges, police officers, etc).
examples: He is studying for a career in law.
She has practiced law in New York for twenty years.

entries.meaning: Jurisprudence, the field of knowledge which encompasses these rules.
examples: She went to university to study law.

entries.meaning: Litigation; legal action (as a means of maintaining or restoring order, redressing wrongs, etc).
examples: They were quick to go to law.

entries.meaning: (now uncommon) An allowance of distance or time (a head start) given to a weaker (human or animal) competitor in a race, to make the race more fair.
(aviation) A mode of operation of the flight controls of a fly-by-wire aircraft.
examples: normal law; alternate law; direct law

entries.meaning: (fantasy) One of two metaphysical forces ruling the world in some fantasy settings, also called order, and opposed to chaos.
(law, chiefly historical) An oath sworn before a court, especially disclaiming a debt. (Chiefly in the phrases "wager of law", "wage one's law", "perform one's law", "lose one's law".)

verbs.description: law (third-person singular simple present laws, present participle lawing, simple past and past participle lawed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To work as a lawyer; to practice law.
(transitive, intransitive, chiefly dialectal) To prosecute or sue (someone), to litigate.
examples: Your husband's [...] so given to lawing, they say. I doubt he'll leave you poorly off when he dies.

entries.meaning: (nonstandard) To rule over (with a certain effect) by law; to govern.
(informal) To enforce the law.
To subject to legal restrictions.

description: From Middle English lawe, from Old English hlāw (“burial mound”). Also spelled low.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A tumulus of stones.
(Northern England, Scotland, archaic) A hill.

description: From Middle English lagh, from Old Norse lag (“that which is lying or laid, position, price, way, sting, blow”), from Proto-Germanic *lagą (“that which is laid”). Cognate with Scots lauch (“one's tavern-reckoning or one's share of the cost, a score; a payment for drink or entertainment”), Middle English lai (“one's share of expenses, one's bill or account”).

entries.meaning: (dialectal or obsolete) A score; share of expense; legal charge.
